name: Heart attack
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Help person sit down and rest in comfortable position
step3: Loosen tight clothing around neck and waist
step4: Ask if they have prescribed heart medication
step5: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR if needed

name: Cardiac arrest
step1: Check responsiveness and breathing
step2: Call emergency services or instruct someone to call
step3: Begin chest compressions immediately - push hard and fast
step4: Use AED if available - follow voice prompts
step5: Continue CPR until help arrives or signs of life return

name: Chest pain (angina)
step1: Call emergency services if pain is severe or worsening
step2: Help person rest in comfortable position
step3: Assist with prescribed angina medication if available
step4: Loosen tight clothing around chest and neck
step5: Monitor vital signs until help arrives

name: Difficulty breathing
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Help person sit upright in comfortable position
step3: Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
step4: Stay calm and reassure the person
step5: Monitor breathing pattern and be ready for CPR if needed

name: Asthma attack
step1: Call emergency services if breathing doesn't improve quickly
step2: Help person use their inhaler if available
step3: Have person sit upright and lean forward slightly
step4: Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
step5: Monitor breathing and stay with person until help arrives

name: Severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Use epinephrine auto-injector if available
step3: Help person lie down with legs elevated
step4: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step5: Stay with person until emergency help arrives

name: Choking (adult)
step1: Ask if person is choking - if can't speak, act immediately
step2: Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver)
step3: Continue thrusts until object is dislodged
step4: If unconscious, begin CPR
step5: Call emergency services if object not dislodged quickly

name: Choking (child)
step1: Check if child can cough or speak
step2: Perform back blows between shoulder blades
step3: Perform chest thrusts if back blows don't work
step4: Call emergency services if object not dislodged
step5: Begin CPR if child becomes unconscious

name: Drowning
step1: Remove person from water safely
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Keep person warm and monitor until help arrives

name: Hyperventilation
step1: Stay calm and speak reassuringly
step2: Have person sit down in quiet area
step3: Encourage slow, deep breathing
step4: Do not use paper bag method
step5: Seek medical help if symptoms persist or worsen

name: COPD flare-up
step1: Call emergency services if breathing severely affected
step2: Help person use prescribed inhalers or nebulizer
step3: Assist person to sit upright in comfortable position
step4: Loosen tight clothing around chest
step5: Monitor breathing and stay with person

name: Severe respiratory infection
step1: Call emergency services for breathing difficulty
step2: Help person sit upright for easier breathing
step3: Provide humidified air if possible
step4: Monitor breathing pattern and oxygen levels
step5: Keep person warm and comfortable

name: Carbon monoxide poisoning
step1: Move person to fresh air immediately
step2: Call emergency services
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Do not re-enter contaminated area

name: Stroke
step1: Use FAST test: Face, Arm, Speech, Time to call emergency
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Keep person comfortable with head elevated
step4: Do not give food, drink, or medication
step5: Monitor breathing and note symptom onset time

name: Seizure (convulsion)
step1: Call emergency services if seizure lasts over 5 minutes
step2: Clear area of hard or sharp objects
step3: Place something soft under head
step4: Do not restrain or put anything in mouth
step5: Roll onto side after seizure ends and monitor breathing

name: Febrile seizure (children)
step1: Place child on soft surface on their side
step2: Do not restrain child or put anything in mouth
step3: Time the seizure duration
step4: Call emergency services if seizure lasts over 5 minutes
step5: Cool child gently after seizure ends

name: Fainting (syncope)
step1: Check responsiveness and breathing
step2: Position person flat on back with legs elevated
step3: Loosen tight clothing around neck and waist
step4: Do not give food or drink until fully alert
step5: Seek medical attention if fainting recurs

name: Head injury (minor)
step1: Apply ice pack to reduce swelling
step2: Monitor for signs of concussion
step3: Keep person awake and monitored for first few hours
step4: Watch for vomiting, confusion, or worsening headache
step5: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen

name: Concussion
step1: Call emergency services for severe symptoms
step2: Keep person still and calm
step3: Apply cold compress to head if no bleeding
step4: Monitor breathing and consciousness level
step5: Do not give medication without medical advice

name: Traumatic brain injury (severe)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person still and support head/neck
step3: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step4: Do not remove helmet if present
step5: Control any bleeding with gentle pressure

name: Unconscious person (unknown cause)
step1: Check responsiveness and breathing
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Place in recovery position if breathing
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Look for medical alert jewelry or identification

name: Severe bleeding (arterial/venous)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Apply direct pressure to wound with clean cloth
step3: Elevate injured area above heart level
step4: Add more layers if blood soaks through
step5: Keep person still and warm until help arrives

name: Nosebleed
step1: Have person sit upright and lean forward
step2: Pinch soft part of nose for 10-15 minutes
step3: Apply ice pack to bridge of nose
step4: Do not tilt head backward
step5: Seek medical help if bleeding continues after 20 minutes

name: Deep cuts / lacerations
step1: Apply direct pressure to control bleeding
step2: Clean wound with running water if possible
step3: Cover with sterile dressing
step4: Seek medical attention for deep wounds
step5: Watch for signs of infection

name: Puncture wound
step1: Allow wound to bleed briefly to clean itself
step2: Clean with running water and mild soap
step3: Apply antibiotic ointment if available
step4: Cover with sterile dressing
step5: Seek medical attention for tetanus shot if needed

name: Amputation (finger/limb)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step3: Elevate injured area
step4: Wrap amputated part in clean, damp cloth and place in plastic bag
step5: Keep amputated part cool but do not freeze

name: Internal bleeding (suspected)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person lying flat and still
step3: Monitor breathing and consciousness
step4: Keep person warm with blanket
step5: Do not give food or drink

name: Gunshot wound
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Apply direct pressure to bleeding areas
step3: Do not remove embedded objects
step4: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step5: Keep person still and warm until help arrives

name: Stab wound
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not remove embedded object
step3: Apply pressure around wound, not on object
step4: Monitor breathing and consciousness
step5: Keep person still and warm

name: Animal bites (dog, cat)
step1: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step2: Clean wound thoroughly with soap and water
step3: Apply antibiotic ointment if available
step4: Cover with sterile dressing
step5: Seek medical attention for rabies risk and infection

name: Minor burns (first degree)
step1: Cool burn with cool running water for 10-15 minutes
step2: Do not use ice or butter on burn
step3: Apply aloe vera or burn cream if available
step4: Cover loosely with sterile non-stick dressing
step5: Watch for signs of infection

name: Moderate burns (second degree)
step1: Cool burn with cool running water for 10-20 minutes
step2: Do not break blisters
step3: Cover loosely with sterile non-stick dressing
step4: Elevate burned area if possible
step5: Seek medical attention for proper treatment

name: Severe burns (third degree)
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not remove burned clothing stuck to skin
step3: Cover burn loosely with sterile non-stick dressing
step4: Elevate burned area if possible
step5: Monitor for shock and breathing difficulties

name: Electrical burns
step1: Ensure power source is off before touching person
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Cover burns with sterile dressing
step5: Monitor for cardiac issues - be ready for CPR

name: Chemical burns
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Brush off dry chemicals before flushing
step3: Flush with cool running water for 15-20 minutes
step4: Remove contaminated clothing carefully
step5: Cover loosely with sterile dressing

name: Sunburn (severe)
step1: Move to shaded or indoor area immediately
step2: Apply cool compresses or take cool bath
step3: Apply aloe vera or moisturizing lotion
step4: Drink plenty of water to prevent dehydration
step5: Seek medical help for blisters, fever, or severe pain

name: Smoke inhalation
step1: Move person to fresh air immediately
step2: Call emergency services
step3: Check breathing and responsiveness
step4: Begin CPR if not breathing
step5: Monitor for respiratory distress until help arrives

name: Fracture (broken bone)
step1: Keep injured area still and supported
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling
step3: Elevate injured limb if possible
step4: Do not try to straighten or realign bone
step5: Seek medical attention for proper treatment

name: Dislocation
step1: Keep injured area still and supported
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling
step3: Do not try to put joint back in place
step4: Seek immediate medical attention
step5: Monitor circulation beyond injury site

name: Sprain
step1: Rest injured area
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
step3: Use compression bandage to reduce swelling
step4: Elevate injured area above heart level
step5: Seek medical help if severe pain or unable to bear weight

name: Strain
step1: Rest injured muscle
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
step3: Use compression bandage if helpful
step4: Elevate injured area if possible
step5: Apply heat after 48 hours for muscle relaxation

name: Spinal injury
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person still - do not move unless absolutely necessary
step3: Support head and neck in position found
step4: Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
step5: Do not remove helmet if present

name: Pelvic injury
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Keep person still and do not move them
step3: Monitor breathing and circulation
step4: Keep person warm with blanket
step5: Do not give food or drink

name: Crushed limb
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not remove crushing object if recently applied
step3: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step4: Keep person still and warm
step5: Monitor breathing and consciousness

name: Swollen joint (possible infection/injury)
step1: Rest injured joint
step2: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
step3: Elevate injured area above heart level
step4: Use compression bandage if helpful
step5: Seek medical attention for proper diagnosis

name: Rib fracture
step1: Help person find comfortable breathing position
step2: Apply ice pack to injured area
step3: Encourage shallow breathing to prevent pneumonia
step4: Seek medical attention for proper diagnosis
step5: Monitor for breathing difficulties

name: Road accident (vehicle collision)
step1: Ensure scene is safe before approaching
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check all involved persons for responsiveness
step4: Do not move injured persons unless in immediate danger
step5: Provide first aid for visible injuries until help arrives

name: Bike or scooter crash
step1: Ensure scene is safe before approaching
step2: Check person's responsiveness and breathing
step3: Do not remove helmet unless necessary for breathing
step4: Stabilize head and neck if spinal injury suspected
step5: Call emergency services for serious injuries

name: Fall from height
step1: Call emergency services immediately
step2: Do not move person unless absolutely necessary
step3: Stabilize head and neck in position found
step4: Monitor breathing and consciousness
step5: Control any visible bleeding with direct pressure

name: Heavy object falling on person
step1: Ensure scene is safe before approaching
step2: Call emergency services immediately
step3: Check responsiveness and breathing
step4: Do not remove object if still crushing
step5: Provide first aid for visible injuries

name: Workplace machinery injury
step1: Turn off machinery immediately if safe to do so
step2: Call emergency services
step3: Do not remove person from machinery if trapped
step4: Control bleeding with direct pressure
step5: Monitor breathing and consciousness until help arrives

name: Getting trapped (hand in machine, etc.)
step1: Turn off power to machinery immediately
step2: Call emergency services and fire department
step3: Do not try to force person free
step4: Keep person calm and still
step5: Monitor breathing and provide reassurance
